# ModSeqR

![](reference/figures/WBL_MODSEQR.png)

## Version 1.0.0

**(Updated December 29th 2025)**

***Note***: *This is an early release - changes may occur that
significantly change the functionality and structure of the data and
functions. The user should be aware that subsequent releases may break
code written using earlier releases.*

**ModSeqR** is an R package managing Direct Whole Methylome Sequencing
(dWMS) data. It creates a database, and processes it with unique
options. Data can be summarized by positions, windows, or provided an
annotation bed file, by unique genomic regions. The package also offers
quality control functions, differential methylation, and a sliding
window analysis.

## Installation

For easy visualization and data management, we encourage you to download
and use RStudio. RStudio download instructions can be found
[here](https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/).

``` r
# Install the devtools package if necessary
install.packages("devtools")

# Install ModSeqR from GitHub
devtools::install_github("Wasatch-Biolabs-Bfx/ModSeqR", build_vignettes = FALSE)

# Access Package
library(ModSeqR)
```

***For Linux Users:*** *System packages may need to be intalled in order
to use devtools. Instructions can be found online. An example guide for
this can be found
[here](https://www.digitalocean.com/community/tutorials/how-to-install-r-packages-using-devtools-on-ubuntu-16-04).*

## Creating .ch3 Files

If your sequencing data is coming from [Wasatch
Biolabs](https://www.wasatchbiolabs.com/), `.ch3` files can be delivered
directly with your batch upon request. These files contain methylation
calls from a third-generation sequencing run. Typically, one .ch3 file
is created per sample, and each file compresses large amounts of raw
data into a usable intermediate format.

If .ch3 files were not provided, you can build them yourself using the
make_ch3_archive() function in this package. This takes a tab-delimited
file of methylation calls (such as the output of modkit extract-calls)
and compresses it into .ch3 format for downstream use.

``` r
# Convert a calls.tsv file to compressed .ch3 format
make_mod_archive(
  file_name   = "calls.tsv",   # input modkit calls file
  sample_name = "sample1",     # will be embedded in output filenames
  out_path    = "output_dir/", # where to write .ch3 files
  short_ids   = TRUE           # optionally shorten read_id to reduce size
)
```

### Important:

- .ch3 files use 0-based, half-open genome coordinates (like BED files).
- Example: a CpG at base 1000 (1-based) will appear as start=999,
  end=1001.
- Each output archive is written in compressed Parquet format (zstd),
  typically producing multiple .ch3 files per sample (e.g.,
  sample1-0.ch3, sample1-1.ch3).

## Example Data

If you’d like to test the package without generating your own .ch3
files, small example data are included with the package in:

`ModSeqR/inst/extdata/ch3_files/`

You can download these example .ch3 files directly from the GitHub
repository under the inst/extdata/ch3_files folder.

These test files can be used to practice building a database and running
the full analysis workflow.

``` r
# Example: build a test database using included example files
example_path <- system.file("extdata/ch3_files", package = "ModSeqR")
mod_db <- make_mod_db(example_path, db_name = "example_db")
```

## Instructions

Begin with .ch3 files created by Wasatch Biolabs or individually, and
build a database using
[`make_mod_db()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/make_mod_db.md).
This will at first hold a calls table. If you would like to see key
stats on your CH3 file, call
[`get_mod_stats()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/get_mod_stats.md).
This shows information like CpG coverage, calls by flag value, high
confidence calls, high quality calls, and average read length.

### Summarize Data

After a database is created, a user can summarize their data by position
([`summarize_mod_positions()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/summarize_mod_positions.md)),
by regions
([`summarize_mod_regions()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/summarize_mod_regions.md)),
by windows
([`summarize_mod_windows()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/summarize_mod_windows.md)),
or by reads
(([`summarize_mod_reads()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/summarize_mod_reads.md)).

### Differential Methylation

A differential methylation analysis can be conducted on positional,
regional, or window data using
[`calc_mod_diff()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/calc_mod_diff.md).
After calculating methylation differences between windows, use
[`collapse_mod_windows()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/collapse_mod_windows.md)
to collapse significant windows in a methylation dataset. This merges
contiguous regions that meet the specified criteria.

### Get Database Stats

If you would like to see key stats on your database at any time,
including what unique sample names are in the data for a differential
analysis, call
[`get_mod_dbinfo()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/get_mod_dbinfo.md).
To see what columns are in a table in your database and how many records
(rows) there are, call
[`get_mod_tableinfo()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/get_mod_tableinfo.md)
with your database and desired table name.

### Quality Control

[`run_mod_qc()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/run_mod_qc.md)
can be called to visually assess any data. Running a QC can take a long
time on large data, so set the argument `max_rows` to a reasonable value
(ex. 1000) to assess data faster. To view and extract a table, call
`export_table()` to export any data table from the database to a file,
or use `get_table()` to import as a tibble into your local environment.
Similarily, use `max_calls` if you are fine with a smaller, randomized
set of data.

If you would like to run everything in one command, call
[`run_mod_analysis()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/run_mod_analysis.md).

## Paradigm

You can pipe your functions together, or feel free to call each function
one line at a time. Below are two examples of this.

``` r
setwd("/home/directory/analysis")

# Build database and run analysis in a pipe
mod_db <- make_mod_db(
  ch3_files = "../ch3_files_directory", 
             db_name = "my_data") |>
  summarize_mod_windows() |>
  calc_mod_diff(call_type = "windows",
              cases =
                c("sperm"),
              controls =
                c("blood")) |>
  collapse_mod_windows() 
  
# Build and analyze through separate lines
mod_db <- make_mod_db(ch3_files = "../ch3_files_directory", db_name = "my_data")
mod_db <- summarize_mod_windows(mod_db)
mod_db <- calc_mod_diff(mod_db, call_type = "windows", cases = c("sperm"), controls = c("blood"))
mod_db <- collapse_mod_windows(mod_db) 

# Run entire differential methylation analysis in one function
run_mod_analysis(mod_db, 
             out_path = "/analysis",
             call_type = "windows",
             cases = c("sperm"),
             controls = c("blood"))

# Check to see what's in your database at any time
get_mod_dbinfo(mod_db)

# Check to see the columns in any table 
get_mod_tableinfo(mod_db, "windows")

# Export differentially methylated data to your computer
export_mod_table(mod_db, "collapsed_windows", "../results_directory")

# OR, to work with your data locally in your R environment
positions <- get_mod_table(mod_db, "positions")
windows <- get_mod_table(mod_db, "windows")
regions <- get_mod_table(mod_db, "regions")

#DONE! Data has been analyzed and exported!
```

***Warning*** *- If using samples other than human or with unique
chromosome names, remember to adjust the chrs argument in each
function!*

### Convenience Functions

ModSeqR also provides a few helper utilities to make it easier to
inspect and manage your database:

``` r
# View all column names in a given table
get_mod_cols(mod_db, "calls")

# Count unique CpG sites (based on start/end)
get_mod_cpg_count(mod_db, table_name = "calls")

# Show high-level database statistics (size, tables, sample names)
get_mod_dbinfo(mod_db)

# Get detailed information about a specific table
get_mod_tableinfo(mod_db, "positions")

# Rename sample names inside any table
rename_mod_samples(mod_db, "positions",
                   samples_map = c("old_name" = "new_name"))

# Remove a table from the database
remove_mod_table(mod_db, "temp_table")
```

## Getting Help

To see detailed documentation on a specific function in R, call
`?{function}`. Example:

``` r
?make_mod_db()
```

This will render development documentation for that function in the Help
tab in Rstudio

### Vignette

To get detailed instructions and help working through the package,
download and view our vignette in this github repo at
`docs/ModSeqRWalkthrough.html`.

Or, build and follow along the vignette by calling:

``` r
browseVignettes("ModSeqR")
```

in R and click on HTML in your browser. Or, to browse the vignette in
your R environment, call

``` r
vignette("ModSeqRWalkthrough")
```

# Package index

## All functions

- [`ModSeqR-package`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/ModSeqR.md)
  [`ModSeqR`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/ModSeqR.md)
  : ModSeqR: Methylation Data Analysis from Nanopore Sequencing
- [`calc_mod_diff()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/calc_mod_diff.md)
  : Calculate Differential Methylation
- [`calc_mod_samplecor()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/calc_mod_samplecor.md)
  : Correlation Matrix of Modified Sequence Data
- [`classify_mod_reads()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/classify_mod_reads.md)
  : Classify Reads as Case or Control Based on Methylation Profiles
- [`collapse_mod_windows()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/collapse_mod_windows.md)
  : Collapse Windows Based on Methylation Differences
- [`export_mod_table()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/export_mod_table.md)
  : Export Tables from the mod Database
- [`filter_mod_table()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/filter_mod_table.md)
  : Filter a DuckDB Table and Save to a New Table
- [`get_mod_cols()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/get_mod_cols.md)
  : Get Column Names from a DuckDB Table
- [`get_mod_cpg_count()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/get_mod_cpg_count.md)
  : Count unique CpG sites in a mod database table
- [`get_mod_dbinfo()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/get_mod_dbinfo.md)
  : Get Database Statistics
- [`get_mod_stats()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/get_mod_stats.md)
  : Compute Statistics for a Ch3 File
- [`get_mod_table()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/get_mod_table.md)
  : Collect Table from DuckDB Database as Tibble
- [`get_mod_tableinfo()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/get_mod_tableinfo.md)
  : Get Table Information from mod Database
- [`make_mod_archive()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/make_mod_archive.md)
  : Create a Compressed Methylation Call Archive (.ch3) from a calls
  file.
- [`make_mod_db()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/make_mod_db.md)
  : Create a Modifications DuckDB from Parquet CH3 files (with optional
  sample naming)
- [`plot_mod_cov()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/plot_mod_cov.md)
  : Calculate and Plot Coverage Statistics
- [`plot_mod_diff()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/plot_mod_diff.md)
  : Plot Differential Methylation Volcano Raster
- [`plot_mod_diff_density()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/plot_mod_diff_density.md)
  : Plot Case vs Control Methylation Fractions with Density-Weighted
  Points
- [`plot_mod_modfrac()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/plot_mod_modfrac.md)
  : Get Methylation Statistics from the Modifications Database
- [`plot_mod_pca()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/plot_mod_pca.md)
  : Perform PCA on Methylation Data
- [`print(`*`<mod_db>`*`)`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/print.mod_db.md)
  : Helper Function to Print Database Tables
- [`remove_mod_table()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/remove_mod_table.md)
  : Remove a table from a database connection.
- [`rename_mod_samples()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/rename_mod_samples.md)
  : Rename sample names in a table
- [`run_mod_analysis()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/run_mod_analysis.md)
  : Run Differential Analysis on Methylation Data
- [`run_mod_dplyr()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/run_mod_dplyr.md)
  : Execute an Expression on a DuckDB Table with Optional
  Materialization
- [`run_mod_qc()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/run_mod_qc.md)
  : Quality Control Wrapper for Methylation Data
- [`run_mod_sql()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/run_mod_sql.md)
  : Execute a query on a mod Database
- [`summarize_mod_positions()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/summarize_mod_positions.md)
  : Summarize per-position methylation calls into a DuckDB table
- [`summarize_mod_reads()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/summarize_mod_reads.md)
  : Summarize Reads in a Database
- [`summarize_mod_regions()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/summarize_mod_regions.md)
  : Summarize methylation by annotated regions
- [`summarize_mod_windows()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/summarize_mod_windows.md)
  : Summarize methylation in sliding windows
- [`trim_mod_reads()`](https://wasatch-biolabs-bfx.github.io/ModSeqR/reference/trim_mod_reads.md)
  : Trim methylation calls at the read ends in a mod database
